Review Title: Beautiful temple with mountains in the background.
Review Text: The temple is built in places visited by Buddha on his first visit to Sri Lanka. Behind the temple stands the Knuckles Mountain Range, which enhances the atmosphere of this place.

Review Title: Ancient sacred temple, must visit for Buddhists
Review Text: This is a very sacred Buddhist religious place in Sri Lanka. It is believed to be the first Buddhist stupa built in Sri Lanka 🇱🇰. This is also the place Buddha stayed when he first visited the island. Apart from the religious importance, this is a very beautiful and calm temple. We visited at night time and it was really peaceful with less crowd. A must visit place for Buddhists .

Review Title: Mahiyangana Temple, Mahiyangana, Badulla District,  Sri Lanka
Review Text: Mahiyangana temple is ancient temple in Sri Lanka. Accoding to ancient  records,  Load Buddha  came to this place and this was one place among sixteen places. Mahiyanga stupa was renovated  by King Dutugamunu and other several kings.
Mahiyangana Raja Maha Viharaya is believed to he the first visit of Gautama Buddha. And it is an ancient historical site situated in Mahiyangana

My wife, our grandson and I visited The Mahiyangana temple early morning on 22nd July 2019.  After parking our car, we walked along the 150 metre long eastern paved path leading to the gleaming bell shaped white stupa accentuated against the lush green mountain range beyond.  I later found that there are four entrances on the four sides.  At each of these entrances is a moon stone with carved animals, clearly wasted by the many feet trudging over them.  On either side of the moon stones are two sculpted guardian figures about 750mm high.  There were many devotees who had come to pay homage at this Stupa.  We joined them and circled around along with other devotees while capturing some interesting photographs. I learned that this had been the first stupa built in Sri Lanka.  Records show that it had been renovated by King Dutugamunu in the second century bc.  It had since been renovated on several occasions.  The height of the stupa stands at 120 feet (37 metres).  This is a prominent cultural attraction that had been declared as a protected archaeological site. On the western side of the Stupa sits the image house.  We saw many devotees there.  A Hindu kovil (temple) dedicated to the deity 'Saman' is also prominent.  No photographs were permitted within the image house and the kovil.  A sculpted statue of future Buddha Maitri sits behind the image house. Even though it was early morning on a weekday, there were many devotees paying their respects by offering flowers and engaging in prayers, seated on the white sands, in typical elevated - hands together posture. A new buddha statue that would be 84 feet (25.2m) high is under construction, a little away towards the south-east of the stupa. We spent a little over an hour at the Mahiyangana temple. Entrance to the temple is free. Visitors are expected to dress modestly and behave with decorum as well as remove their footwear before entering the temple premises.
It is more than worth to visit this temple, surrounded by locals and no tourists , it gives a special feeling. We visited in march 2018 , but this is not anymore on the list0

Review Title: A very sacred place. Highly commercialized.
Review Text: A huge temple and a very significant temple in Sri Lanka. Always having some devotees. When it rains can get very muddy.

Review Title: One of the most sacred places in Sri Lanka
Review Text: This is the first place where Lord Gauthama Buddha has visited in Sri Lanka. So for all the Buddhist people, this place is very important. This is located in Mahiyanganaya City and please wear a suitable dress here, even though you're on a fun trip. Here you can explore a bit about the Buddhist culture.
very nice place..it feels very comfortable for life.so happy to stay long time there.very good place for buddhist place

We had a wonderful visit to this very historic temple despite the awful weather - it was pouring with rain and skies were grey as my photos show. Nevertheless, we waded through flooded paths to see it and were not disappointed. It has a magnificent approach with a long pathway lined with a wall that has elephants along it. This is reached through crossing a moonstone. The stupa is huge and the atmosphere peaceful and spiritual. This temple is very famous as it is believed to be the site of the Buddha's first visit to the island.
Main attraction of Mahiyanganaya is the Mahiyangana Temple.. This is the perahara season for Mahiyanganaya.. must visit place if you are a budhdhist

Mahiyangana Raja Maha Vihara is an ancient Buddhist temple in Mahiyangana, Sri Lanka. It is believed to be the site of Gautama Buddha's first visit to the country, and is one of the Solosmasthana, the 16 sacred religious locations in Sri Lanka.

Mahiyangana Raja Maha Vihara is an ancient Buddhist temple in Mahiyangana, Sri Lanka. It is believed to be the site of Gautama Buddha's first visit to the country, and is one of the Solosmasthana, the 16 sacred religious locations in Sri Lanka.
Authorities should take nessesory steps to preserve the beauty of this heritage site. Information center would be a good additive with some security staff and proper housekeeping.

PLEASE NOTE!!! This is a review for Veddha people in Dambana Village near Mahiyanganaya, Sri Lanka (which I cannot find in any list of trip advisor). I was so eager to meet with these people, I visited their village and I tried to arrange a co-existance for 1-2 nights for the 3 of us of our group. First of all, the village was empty, then they would let us be with them without water supply, toilets and beds, just with 2 or 3 meals, they would show us the way they hunt (no hunting during August), they would show us some of their dance and songs... AND they asked for 70 euros per person per night. After our denial to accept this, we went to another settlement  near by to be informed that they would just arrange for a show with some music, dance and singing, then they would show us around the place and the way they hunt for 35 euros per person. Since our aim was to live with them some days we were so disappointed we left with the most negative impression. So, I can say without any fear, that the Veddha people attraction is a FRAUD...don't even bother to go and see them. As in most tourist attractions in Sri Lanka, their only aim is to get the "bloody tourists'" money and if you are sensitive enough, you will feel their dislike against "westerners" who they feel as responsible for all their poverty problems. I have to repeat what I say every time I write about Sri Lanka. It is one of the most beautiful countries I ever visited (top 3 of 35 I visited), its people are the sweetest of all I ever met, BUT in tourist industry they are unacceptable amateurs.

A two hour bus ride from Kandy, the 'Mahiyangana Raja Maha Vihara' is a sprawling and scenic site of pilgrimage and veneration. You will love the ten kilometre, winding road that descends onto the plains of Uva Province. Sunrise and sunset are rather nice. There is a fee payable at the main ticketing box located opposite the main Vihara, where you will receive a lovely, glossy, folded information brochure. The grounds are expansive and photo opportunities are certainly available.... ... But not in the shrine room, of the main Vihara. The resident Sangha are friendly and welcoming. Bring 'dana' gifts and donation money with you, for the till boxes. Monks can only possess what is given too them. Unless the community provides, they go without. Shop in Kandy before arriving and fill up a big box full of things that you would appreciate having, if you were living life as a Monk. The museum is small and quaint. The local 'stray dogs' seem friendly. The most shocking accommodation options that I have seen in Sri Lanka are available. You're better off sleeping at the Monastery, returning to Kandy City or moving on (immediately) after your visit.

It was visited by Buddha during his first visit to Sri Lanka, by playing role to mediate and calm the conflict of two tribes living there originally and turned the area and people to be Buddha's followers.
We visited on our way back to Kandy after visiting the Vedda tribe. Great place to stop and wander around, although the large elephant at the rear that was chained up didn't look to happy.

Mahiyanganaya Dagoba has a very good written history and it is one of the symbolic icon of Buddhists. Every Buddhist must visit at least one before end their life time and worship. Very peaceful area with beautiful nature as well. Must visit place for Pilgrim tour.

Mahiyanganaya is a town situated close to the Mahaweli River in Badulla District, Uva Province of Sri Lanka. It is said that the Lord Gautama Buddha visited Mahiyanganaya on the full moon Poya day of January in order to settle a dispute arose between Yakkas and Nagas (two tribes then inhabited this area) and this was his first ever visit to Sri Lanka. Then the Lord Buddha preached Dhamma to Sumana Saman, a leader in this area, to whom the Lord Buddha gave a handful of his hair relic so that people could worship. After that Sumana Saman (now the God Sumana Saman) built a golden chethiya in which the sacred hair relic was deposited. Later on about seven chethiyas were built over the original golden chethiya from time to time, the last one being built by the King Dutugemunu. As such, this historic town is a very sacred place for Buddhists.

At Mahiyangana Temple one can find the worlds first Buddhist Stupa which was built with the knowledge of Lord Buddha it self  during his first visit to Sri lanka just nine months after his enlightenment. The Stupa was built by God saman with a height 7 cubits placing Hair relics of Buddha given by Buddha himself in 6 BCE. subsequently monk Sarabu increased the height up to 12 cubits placing the GREEVA Daathu (Throat Bone relic) of Lord  Buddha,  then King Uddachulabaya increased the hight up to 30 cubit and King Dutugamunu increased the stupa to the present height of 80 cubits. Stupa is located in a beautiful location, on the side of range of mountains and river Mahaweli.
One of the three spots Buddha came in Sri Lanka; the area is very clean (not like Kataragama); no entry fee!; a lot of attractions
